section.title: 1.5 Measurements and Conversions
section.content: 1.5 Measurements and Conversions 1.5 Measurements and Conversions
section.related-content: This is Module 1.5 Measurements and Conversions. The purpose of this session is to familiarize the student with different units of measurement that he may encounter in this course and in his daily work in a technical field.

section.title: Measurement
section.content: Why measure: Common benchmarks Consistency Prevent fraud – Laws Easy to use Standards development Agreed by trading partners Progression to widely accepted standards International System (SI) Measurement Why measure: Common benchmarks Consistency Prevent fraud – Laws Easy to use Standards development Agreed by trading partners Progression to widely accepted standards International System (SI) Measurement
section.related-content:
Measurement is the assignment of a number to a characteristic of an object or event, which can be compared with other objects or events.
Over the course of human history, first for convenience and then for necessity, standards of measurement evolved so that communities would have certain common benchmarks and a consistent understanding of quantities. Laws regulating measurement were originally developed to prevent fraud in commerce. Therefore, they had to be easy to use and interpret. At first, these standards were achieved by local agreements between trading partners or collaborators. Since the 18th century, developments progressed towards unifying, widely accepted standards. Some of that progression was due to multinational companies that needed standards in their measurements for consistent trade. Therefore, separate systems originated in countries such as England – that is the Imperial system who had colonies all over the world. Finally, there was recognition that a global standard was necessary for consistency between countries, traders and scientists. That resulted in the modern International System of Units (SI) being developed. Remnants of the older systems still exist to complicate things, but most modern countries now use this international standard.

section.related-content:
The International System of Units (abbreviated SI from the French Le Système International d'Unités) is the modern form of the metric system and is generally a system devised around the convenience of the base number 10. We will discuss some of the exceptions to this practice as we progress through this module. It is the world's most widely used system of units, both in everyday commerce and in science.
One common example, in the SI system is a unit of weight or mass is the kilogram. There are 1000 grams in a kilogram. Many of our day to day food products and our body weight is expressed in kilograms. The unit of length is the meter. There are 1000 meters in a kilometer. The height of an individual is usually expressed in meters and the speed of a car is commonly expressed in kilometers per hour.
Many monetary systems in the world are based on a system of ten also. For instance, the Indian system is based on the rupee with one paisa being a decimal part of a rupee – one hundredth of a rupee. Monetary systems are unique for each country and are not standardized between countries. Therefore, comparisons are much more difficult. The values they express vary depending on many circumstances. They are not part of the SI system.
A uniform system allows us to communicate in a standard language of measurement so we can understand the relationships between measurements, understand baselines and compare progress. It is much the same when we converse in Hindi as a common language because we all do not all converse in Bengali.
In this course, we will encounter a variety of measurements that are required for us to understand the carbon black process and the science related to this process. To be consistent, we will use the SI system of measurement. The examples in this module are not meant to be a complete representation of all the conversions available in the SI system. If you would like further information, there is an extensive list of conversions on the Internet.

As part of an international company, our standard unit of measurement in Himadri is the SI system. Because we are in an International commerce system, conversions to U.S., Imperial, or other units of measurement or other systems may be required on an infrequent basis. We will not concentrate on these type conversions because they will not be common in our everyday practice.
In this course, we will encounter a variety of measurements that are required for us to understand the carbon black process and the science related to this process. To be consistent, we will use the SI system of measurement. The purpose of the SI system of measurement is to reduce all Base quantities to combinations of seven properties as follows: Time, Length, Mass, Electric Current, Temperature, Amount of Substance, and Luminous Intensity. We will briefly cover each of these properties in this overview and some of the applications we will experience in our work environment.

section.title: Time
section.content: Time in our SI system is expressed in standard units of seconds. Irregular system has evolved over the centuries. System based on the number 10 Except in expressing very short measurements such as milliseconds or microseconds. Time Time in our SI system is expressed in standard units of seconds. Irregular system has evolved over the centuries. System based on the number 10 Except in expressing very short measurements such as milliseconds or microseconds. Time
section.related-content:
Time, is a subject that is very familiar to us all, though not very consistent in the common units used. Time in our SI system is expressed in standard units of seconds, although many standard time frames are used including minutes which are 60 seconds and hours which are 60 minutes or 3600 seconds. Then there is one earth rotation equivalent to a day of 24 hours. Then we get into the time required for the earth to travel one complete orbit around the sun which is called a years. This irregular system has evolved over the centuries and is still in use as the common method of expressing time used in the world. Perhaps some day, we will change the system to a system based on the number 10 but, except in expressing very short measurements, such as milliseconds or microseconds, this is not common today.
The most commonly used units of time are as follows where
 60 seconds = 1 minute
 60 minutes = 1 hour
 24 hours = 1 day
Some non-systematic uses of time are as follows:
10 years = 1 decade; 100 years = 1 century; 1000 years = 1 millennium
Time is commonly used to help express a rate of progression such as the production of carbon black in kilograms per day, use of oil in kilograms of oil per hour, and air speeds in meters per second. We are interested in benchmarking many phenomena in our plant in elapsed time periods so we can set standards and improve.

section.title: Length
section.content: Length MillimeterCentimeterMeterKilometer 1/100 meter 1/1000 meter 1000 meters Metric units of length Length MillimeterCentimeterMeterKilometer 1/100 meter 1/1000 meter 1000 meters Metric units of length
section.related-content:
In the SI unit system, the common unit of measure for length is a meter. Length is the linear distance between two points. Each of the subunits of measurement in this system is a decimal unit of measurement in relationship to the meter. The centimeter which is one one-hundredth of a meter is about the thickness of my small finger but think how different measurements would be if everyone used his small finger to measure the length of something, such as a pipeline.
Since length is about visible dimensions, the human eye has a range of vision from objects that are small insects to the size of a whale and beyond. A carbon black pellet agglomerate may be 2 to 3 millimeters in length (or diameter). To see smaller dimensions, a light microscope can be used to measure the size of objects down to micrometers in length. With carbon black particles we need an electron microscope to measure objects that are as small as 10 nanometers – or ten billionths of a meter - in size.

section.title: Mass (and Weight)
section.content: Difficult terms to understands “Scientifically” Weight depends upon acceleration such as gravity. Gravity – Variable force Mass is independent of gravity. The weight expressed in kilograms. 1000 grams in a kilogram. kilograms sometimes referred to “kilos” Feedstock oil measured in kilograms or metric tons Inventories of carbon black in kilograms or metric tons Mass (and Weight) Difficult terms to understands “Scientifically” Weight depends upon acceleration such as gravity. Gravity – Variable force Mass is independent of gravity. The weight expressed in kilograms. 1000 grams in a kilogram. kilograms sometimes referred to “kilos” Feedstock oil measured in kilograms or metric tons Inventories of carbon black in kilograms or metric tons Mass (and Weight)
section.related-content:
Mass and weight are similar but sometimes difficult terms to understand “scientifically” because the weight of an object depends upon an acceleration such as gravity. Gravity is a variable force depending on where you are on the earth or in the universe. For instance, the moon, the weight of a person will be only about 17% of that on earth. Mass of an object is independent of gravity or other forces. We won’t get into any more details about these differences here but you do need to understand this basic concept. In most measurements, we are interested in the weight expressed in kilograms. In some engineering calculations we may have to adjust the “weight” expressed in kilograms due to minor gravity influences but these are not common conversions.
In the SI unit system, the standard unit for weight is the kilogram. There are 1000 grams in a kilogram.
Usually if someone is measuring the weight of a relatively large mass such as a person, in the SI system he uses kilograms for that measurement. Weight of vegetables in countries where the SI system is used are typically in kilograms sometimes referred to “kilos” or grams. If we measure larger weights in the SI system, we use metric tons. A metric ton is 1000 kilograms of weight.
Feedstock oil for our plant is commonly measured in weights such as kilograms or metric tons.
Also, our inventories of carbon blacks may be expressed in kilograms or tons of product. Many of our raw materials will be measured in weights so we precisely know how much we have used or how much we have in our inventories.

section.title: Electrical Current
section.content: Electrical Current - Current measured in ampere. Volt Power (watts) = Current (amperes) x Potential (volts) Potential is measured in volts. 1000 watts = 1 kilowatts 1 megawatts = 1000 kilowatts Electricity is a complex and interesting science Electrical Current - Current measured in ampere. Volt Power (watts) = Current (amperes) x Potential (volts) Potential is measured in volts. 1000 watts = 1 kilowatts 1 megawatts = 1000 kilowatts Electricity is a complex and interesting science
section.related-content:
The movement of an electric charge is known as an electric current, the intensity of which is usually measured in amperes. Current can consist of any moving charged particles; most commonly these are electrons, but any charge in motion constitutes a current. Electric current can flow through some substances called electrical conductors, but will not flow through an electric insulator. A lightening storm is a good physical representation of electric current flowing in the atmosphere.
The electric potential difference is the energy required to move a unit charge between two specified points. The volt is the unit used to describe this electric potential difference. This term sees greater everyday usage such as the voltage in a battery used for electronics or car ignition. If we measure the potential between the “plus” and “minus” poles of a battery with a voltmeter, we can discover the voltage potential of the battery. If we measure the flow of electrons, we can discover the current or amperage of the circuit using the battery.
A Watt is one unit of electrical power equal to one ampere under the “pressure” of one volt. This is the common means to measure the power consumed by our electrical circuits, such as lights, electrical heaters and motors and is also the power generated by our electrical generators. Steam generated from tail gas is converted to electrical power.
The power unit of a watt is typically used for small appliances such as a light bulb or a microwave oven. For large motors and generators, the power is expressed as in kilowatts of power, which is 1000 watts. For the generating power of our electrical generators, the power may be expressed in megawatts of power, which is 1000 kilowatts.
In the plant, we are interested in the amount of energy consumed by our electrical circuits which include lighting circuits, motors and electrical heaters. We typically want to know the power required to do some specific work such as moving a gas or liquid through a pipeline so we can understand the energy expended and the cost for that service. To determine the energy consumed, we use a energy term called the watt-hour or the kilowatt-hour which takes the power consumption in watts and projects that usage over a fixed period of time in hours.
Electricity is a complex and interesting science. Our brief discussion here only touches on the basics of this field and the way it is measured.

section.title: Temperature
section.content: Temperature How hot or how cold Measured by a thermometer, thermocouple Indication of internal energy of a substance Unit of measurement is SI system. °Kelvin (K) For our purpose °Centigrade is equal to °Celsius Combustor >2000°C Reactor 1300°C to 1700°C Air Preheater <800°C Bag Filters <300°C Dryer Carbon Black +/- 180°C Temperature How hot or how cold Measured by a thermometer, thermocouple Indication of internal energy of a substance Unit of measurement is SI system. °Kelvin (K) For our purpose °Centigrade is equal to °Celsius Combustor >2000°C Reactor 1300°C to 1700°C Air Preheater <800°C Bag Filters <300°C Dryer Carbon Black +/- 180°C
section.related-content:
Temperature is an objective measurement of how hot or cold an object is. It can be measured with a thermometer, thermocouple or a calorimeter. It is a means of determining the internal energy contained within a given system. We will cover this in more detail when we discuss heat energy and the thermodynamics of heat exchange.
The basic unit of measurement of temperature in the SI system is degrees Kelvin. The Kelvin scale starts at a temperature that is minus 273 degrees Celsius – that is 273 degrees below the freezing point of water which is zero degrees Celsius. This absolute temperature is considered the coldest possible temperature when atoms have their minimum vibrational motion. The Centigrade scale is based on a range of temperature that considers water is frozen at zero degrees Celsius and boils at 100 degrees Celsius under normal atmospheric pressure. There are subtle differences between the terms Centigrade temperatures and Celsius temperatures but for practical purposes the terms can be used interchangeably. Both the Celsius and Centigrade scales are based on the metric system with a base of 10. For everyday uses, we will use the Centigrade scale which fits the temperature ranges we will deal with in the plant. For some more complicated engineering calculations, particularly for gases, we will need to use the Kelvin scale.
In the plant, we use many types of temperature measurements to set our process conditions so we can optimize production, yields and heat transfer. We experience temperatures higher than 2000 degrees Celsius in the combustors used on some of our reactors. The operating temperatures of our reactors range between approximately 1300 degrees Celsius and 1700 degrees Celsius depending on our carbon black product requirements. Hot air preheat for the combustors are in the range of 750 degrees Celsius. Our bag filters are operated under 300 degrees Celsius so not to exceed the bag cloth temperatures. Carbon black temperatures in the dryer are approximately 180 degrees Celsius in order to keep the temperature over the evaporation point of water.
You will find many temperature measurements in our carbon black process and we will review the uses and requirements as we progress through the various modules in this course.

section.title: Amount of a Substance
section.content: Amount of a Substance The mole – fixed number of atoms, molecules, ions, or electrons in a substance Avogadro Number Substances combine in predictable fixed ratios 12C = Carbon with a mole weight of exactly 12 Amount of a Substance The mole – fixed number of atoms, molecules, ions, or electrons in a substance Avogadro Number Substances combine in predictable fixed ratios 12C = Carbon with a mole weight of exactly 12
section.related-content:
The amount of a substance standard used by the SI system of measurement is called a “mole” and is defined by a scientifically fixed number of atoms, molecules, ions or electrons for a substance. We will not get into the actual number and what that means.  The Avogadro number is worth further investigation if you are interested.
We briefly touched on an example of the use of a mole in our Introduction to Carbon Black Chemistry. This measurement is derived from the fact that naturally occurring substances combine in certain fixed ratios to form more complex substances. The atomic or molecular weight of those substances are used to determine the fixed quantity of each element that defines the combination. We can get the molecular and atomic weights from chemical tables or the Periodic table which gives an outline of the properties of all the substances found on the Earth.
The mole is defined by International Bureau of Weights and Measures as "the amount of substance of a system which contains as many elementary entities as there are atoms in 0.012 kilogram of carbon-12." Isn’t it interesting that we produce a type of pure carbon product on which this IS standard is based.
One of the common molecules that we are familiar in everyday life is water, H-two-O. Do you remember the table we used to show the combinations and resulting amounts. When water is formed, two atoms of hydrogen with a relative weight of 1 combine with one atom of oxygen with a relative weight of 16 to form a molecule of water with a relative weight of 18. Since hydrogen is commonly a gas with two hydrogen atoms and oxygen is a gas with two oxygen atoms, the combinations of these gases are required in a ratio of two hydrogen molecules with one molecule of oxygen to make water. At the completion of the reaction, two molecules of water are formed.
Since we have a chemical process where complicated combustion reactions are taking place, we will use this substance background to determine the yield of carbon black from our reactors by analyzing the ‘moles” of raw materials input to the reactor, the reaction combinations, and the analysis of the resulting gases from the process. We can also do other chemical calculations to determine the efficiency of various reactions that we will observe in this course. It’s not that complicated.

section.title: Luminous Intensity
section.content: Luminous Intensity Intensity of light – SI unit - candela Monochromatic green light of frequency 540 THz Radiant intensity of 1/683 watts per ste-radian Luminous Intensity Intensity of light – SI unit - candela Monochromatic green light of frequency 540 THz Radiant intensity of 1/683 watts per ste-radian
section.related-content:
This is a standard that has reference to how we measure the intensity of light. This is the one subject that we will spend very little time exploring since it has little to do with the physical manufacturing of carbon black – The exception is that we will want to have enough visible light to see how to operate the plant and read the various meters safely.
Like other SI base units, the intensity of light is defined by the description of a physical process that will produce one candela of luminous intensity. You can infer by the name of the unit “candela” that the property was developed by relating the light produced to the illumination of a candle. As science progressed, we needed a more scientific definition that was not affected by the size of the candle, the wick, the wax type, etc. So, by definition, if one constructs a light source that emits monochromatic green light with a frequency of 540 TeraHertz, and that has a radiant intensity of 1 divided by 683 watts per ste-radian in a given direction, that light source will emit one candela in the specified direction. Above is a diagram that reflects the various terms that are used to measure some of the properties of light illumination.
You can see from this definition of this standard unit, that much scientific thought has been used to develop each one of these concepts.

section.related-content:
As we continue, we will review several other common measurements used in carbon black technology. As we introduced this module, we presented the seven basic units of measurements of the SI system. From these seven base quantities many other derived quantity units can be formed. We are going to discuss several of these derived units which are listed in the table. These will be measurements that you will need to only understand in general to have a basic understanding about the measurements used in our plant.
The measurement of volume uses the unit of length cubed. So the units of measurement is the cubic meter or if the size of the quantity is smaller, the cubic centimeter. The measurement of pressure uses a term called a Pascal. A Pascal is a force of one Newton pressing on one square meter – in SI units that is one kg per meter per second squared. Heat energy is measured in Joules. One Joule is 1 kilogram per square meter per second squared. Mass flow rate and volumetric flow rate are kilogram per second and cubic meter per second respectively. Usually, we use hourly flow rates so we convert the seconds of flow to hours. We will also discuss carbon black production rates which are derived from the mass flow rates of carbon black. We will also discuss carbon black yields which are derived from the mass flow rates of carbon black and the feedstock and fuels used to produce that amount of carbon black.
As you can see, we are finished with any derived unit measurements concerning electric current, temperature, amount of substance and luminous intensity.

section.title: Volume
section.content: Volume Volume SI units – the cubic meter Liquids Litre – a common measurement of volume in everyday life for liquids such as bottled water or soft drinks. 1000 cubic centimetres in one litre The volume of a liquid may change due to temperature To understand mass quality, the density at a temperature should be referenced Gases Gas Volumes are usually measured by cubic meters For a gas, the volume changes with both temperature and pressure Usually gas volumes are referenced to a “Normal” condition 0°C temperature and 1.01325 bar pressure Volume Volume SI units – the cubic meter Liquids Litre – a common measurement of volume in everyday life for liquids such as bottled water or soft drinks. 1000 cubic centimetres in one litre The volume of a liquid may change due to temperature To understand mass quality, the density at a temperature should be referenced Gases Gas Volumes are usually measured by cubic meters For a gas, the volume changes with both temperature and pressure Usually gas volumes are referenced to a “Normal” condition 0°C temperature and 1.01325 bar pressure
section.related-content:
Volume is the quantity of three-dimensional space enclosed by a closed surface, for example, the space that a substance or shape occupies or contains, such as a water bottle. Volume is often quantified numerically using the SI derived unit, the cubic meter or when the quantities are small, cubic centimeters.
In the SI system, one common unit of measurement of volumes of liquids is the liter which can be found in shops for bottled water, soft drinks and myriad other products. A liter is 1000 cubic centimeters in volume.
The volume of a fixed mass of liquid may change due to temperature. You can see the volume of water expand when heated for making tea or coffee. Therefore, a reference to a liquid’s temperature should be noted when measuring a certain volume of that liquid.
Gas volumes are also usually measured in cubic meters. However, gas volumes change due to both pressures and temperatures. For ideal or perfect gases, the gas volumes change. In order to define a gas volume perfectly, the temperature and pressure of that gas must be measured as well. A standard cubic meter referenced to a volume at zero degrees Celsius and a pressure of 1.0135 bar is called a NORMAL cubic meter. For a gas at Normal temperature and pressure, 22.4 liters of the gas constitutes one molar volume of the gas. This is a convenient conversion factor to determine the mass of the gas for reaction calculations.

section.related-content:
Pressure means how much something is pushing on something else. It is expressed as force per unit area. One common example of pressure is the pressure cooker where the contents of a pot are heated until the pressure of the steam inside the pot rises and elevates the temperature to a point that the contents are cooked quickly. Also, the LPG used for cooking is under pressure in a bottle. We can use the pressure of the LPG to give an indication of the contents remaining.
The force of one Newton pressing on an area of one square meter is one Pascal, a derived SI unit we discussed earlier. In the plant we use pressure gauges that measure in bars, a non- SI unit which is defined as 100,000 Pascal or 100,000 Newtons per square meter or one kilogram per square centimeter. One atmosphere pressure or 1 kilogram force per square centimeter is 98.0665 kilo Pascals. One bar is approximately 1 atmosphere of pressure at sea level, actually 0.987 atmospheric pressure at sea level. Pressure is often specified in multiples of atmospheric pressure. 
Since most pressure measurements are made open to the earth’s atmospheric pressure system, we normally call these measurements “gauge” pressures because the baseline pressure, zero, is the atmospheric pressure. “Absolute” pressure is based on a reference point of a complete vacuum which is zero pressure in this reference state. Normally, we need to consider only gauge pressure for our most basic measurements in our process and most of our “pressure gauges” measure at this pressure. Sometimes a “g” is added is added to the pressure reading to clarify that this is gauge pressure not absolute pressure. A vacuum is normally measured as a negative gauge pressure. If during the course of a comparison it is required to change gauge pressure to absolute pressure, you must add the atmospheric pressure in the same units to the gauge pressure.
In the plant we will use many gauge pressures. As we stated earlier, the pressure and temperature of a gas are required in order to define the mass of the gas we have available, so in all cases where we measure gases, a pressure is required. We may use pressure gauges to measure baseline pressures but in many cases we use pressure transmitters to measure the pressures so we can see trends in the control room. We also use pressures to measure the differential pressures across orifices to measure flow and for determining the height of a fluid in a tank. We will measure pressures of oil and water sprays so we can monitor the effective atomization, that is droplet size, of that operation. We measure small pressures or negative pressures called vacuums using manometers and these pressures may be in millibars or millimeters of water or mercury.
Pressure measurement is one of the fundamental measurements for plant operations.

section.title: Energy
section.content: Energy Heat or Thermal Energy Energy flow caused by temperature Important factor in carbon black process Large factor in costs SI unit - Joule Used to measure Heat Electricity Mechanical Work Joule (J) Work done by a force of Newton moving one meter OR Work done to produce one Watt of electricity for one second Application Crack hydrocarbons to produce carbon Heat process air and oil to improve efficiency Remove water from wet carbon black pellets Create steam for generating power Energy Heat or Thermal Energy Energy flow caused by temperature Important factor in carbon black process Large factor in costs SI unit - Joule Used to measure Heat Electricity Mechanical Work Joule (J) Work done by a force of Newton moving one meter OR Work done to produce one Watt of electricity for one second Application Crack hydrocarbons to produce carbon Heat process air and oil to improve efficiency Remove water from wet carbon black pellets Create steam for generating power
section.related-content:
In simple terms, heat is an energy flow caused by differences in temperature.
Heat is a very important factor in our carbon black process and a large factor in our costs.
The most common term used in the SI system for heat measurement is the Joule. The Joule – symbol J - is used for measuring heat, electricity and mechanical work. One Joule is the work done, or energy expended, by a force of one Newton moving one meter along the direction of the force. One joule is also the work done to produce the power of one watt continuously for one second.
Heat is used in our process for cracking the hydrocarbon in feedstocks and fuel into carbon black. Heat is generated in this reaction and used to heat process air and oil to make the process more efficient. Heat is used to heat the wet carbon black pellets to remove the water added for pelletization. And one of our primary uses of heat is to create steam that can be converted into electrical energy. Since heat is a by-product of our process, we will find many applications of this subject in our plant.
The concept of heat and thermal energy will be explored in more detail when we discuss each of the process unit operations where heat is used and in a general overview of Thermodynamics.

section.title: Fluid Flow Rates (Mass)
section.content: Fluid Flow Rates (Mass) Liquid measured with mass flow meters Simple to express in mass per unit time Comparisons simple when values are expressed as mass units rather than volume units Mass flow rate = Volumetric flow rate x density Volume per unit time or mass per unit time Under the SI system – measure flow rates in Kilogram or grams per unit time (hours, minutes or seconds) Liquid flow rates for: Feedstock oil: Liquid fuels Water Potassium solutions Binder solutions Others Fluid Flow Rates (Mass) Liquid measured with mass flow meters Simple to express in mass per unit time Comparisons simple when values are expressed as mass units rather than volume units Mass flow rate = Volumetric flow rate x density Volume per unit time or mass per unit time Under the SI system – measure flow rates in Kilogram or grams per unit time (hours, minutes or seconds) Liquid flow rates for: Feedstock oil: Liquid fuels Water Potassium solutions Binder solutions Others
section.related-content:
Flow rates are generally measured in volume per unit time or mass per unit time.
Liquid flows rates are usually measured in mass flow rates of grams per unit time or kilograms per unit time depending on the magnitude of the flow being considered.
In the carbon black process, we are interested in the flow rates for feedstock oil , water, potassium solutions, binder solutions and other substances. It is important that we know the flow rates so we can determine the consumption of each of these substances compared to the carbon black that is produced and for determining the total costs of operation.
Liquids are typically measured with mass flow meters. Then it is simple to express these flow rates in mass per unit time. Determining efficiencies are much simpler when the values are expressed as mass units rather than volume units. This allows all the comparisons to be made in similar units of measurement when making chemical reaction comparisons and determining efficiencies of the process.
If volumetric flow rates are used, then any flow calculations requiring mass flow rates will have to be converted to mass using the density of the fluid being transported.

section.title: Flow rate (Volumetric)
section.content: Flow rate (Volumetric) Volume per unit time or mass per unit time Gas flow rates expressed at constant temperature and pressure If not, relationship of the mass of gas is uncertain Important for understanding efficiency of processes Gaseous flow rates for Process Air Gaseous fuels (LPG or NG) Tail Gas Off Gas Normal cubic meters (Nm3) per hour 0° Celsius temperature 1.01325 bar pressure Molar volume = 22.4 litres at NTP Flow rate (Volumetric) Volume per unit time or mass per unit time Gas flow rates expressed at constant temperature and pressure If not, relationship of the mass of gas is uncertain Important for understanding efficiency of processes Gaseous flow rates for Process Air Gaseous fuels (LPG or NG) Tail Gas Off Gas Normal cubic meters (Nm3) per hour 0° Celsius temperature 1.01325 bar pressure Molar volume = 22.4 litres at NTP
section.related-content:
Flow rates are generally measured in volume per unit time or mass per unit time.
Due to the compressibility of gases, gas flow rates in volume per unit time need to be expressed at a constant temperature and pressure to be meaningful. If the constant temperature and pressure are not expressed, the relationship of the mass of gas being used is uncertain and mass rates are important in understanding how efficient our chemical processes work. Therefore, for measurement of gases a reference temperature and pressure is usually expressed by the term “Normal” in the SI system. The gas flow rates will be expressed in Normal Cubic Meters per hour. In this system of measurement the constant temperature used is always 0 degrees Celsius, or plus 273 degrees Kelvin and the standard pressure is 1.01325 bar absolute. Some of our measurement systems convert the flow measurement in volume per unit time directly to a Normal pressure and temperature, that is to Normal cubic meters so the meter reading is actually in Normal measurement units.
The volume of 1 mole of any gas is called its molar volume and is equal to 22.4 Liters at standard temperature and pressure. Molar volume allows conversions to be made between moles and volumes of gases at standard temperature and pressure. This is a very useful quantity that can be used to calculate molar mass when gases are measured at standard temperatures and pressures and for chemical reaction mass balances.

section.title: Feedstock Yield – Production Throughput
section.content:
Feedstock Yield –
Production Throughput Yield Kilograms of feedstock oil and fuel consumed per kilogram of carbon black produced. Throughput Example Feedstock oil + Fuel per hour = 8000 kg/ hr Yield estimated = 1.6 kg feedstock + fuel/ 1 kg of carbon black Production throughput = 8000/1.6 = 5000 kg/ hr 5000 kg/ hr = x 24 hours per day 120 tons per day = x 365 days per year 43, 800 tons per year Feedstock Yield –
Production Throughput Yield Kilograms of feedstock oil and fuel consumed per kilogram of carbon black produced. Throughput Example Feedstock oil + Fuel per hour = 8000 kg/ hr Yield estimated = 1.6 kg feedstock + fuel/ 1 kg of carbon black Production throughput = 8000/1.6 = 5000 kg/ hr 5000 kg/ hr = x 24 hours per day 120 tons per day = x 365 days per year 43, 800 tons per year
section.related-content:
Carbon black yields in Himadri are expressed in kilograms of oil feedstock and fuel consumed per kilogram of carbon black produced. Other manufacturers use other calculations to represent their yields so carbon black yields are not comparative between producers. This is one calculation that is not consistent in the carbon black industry.
For another type analysis the total carbon black produced can be compared to the feedstock carbon in the feedstock and fuel to get a carbon yield percentage which also is a good indicator of the total process efficiency. This is the ‘carbon efficiency”. Since carbon production is our business, the amount of total carbon we recover from the hydrocarbons is what we finally want to baseline as our efficiency.
In the SI system of measurement, the throughputs of our carbon black production units and plants are normally expressed in kilograms per hour, metric tons per day or metric tons per year. The amount of carbon we produce is assessed and balanced using our standard yields and throughputs then balanced with the inventories we experience as we package the final product. This gives us a good indication of the amount of carbon produced for each product.
As an example, if we use 8000 kilograms of feedstock and fuel and produce a product that has a yield estimate of 1.6 kilogram of feedstock and fuel per kilogram of carbon black, our production throughput would be 5000 kilograms per hour.
If this carbon black production unit produces 5000 kilograms per hour, we can easily convert that to 5 tons per hour times 24 hours per day equals 120 tons per day times 365 days per year equals 43,800 tons per year.

section.title: Accuracy and Precision of Measure
section.content:
Accuracy and Precision of
Measure Uncertainty of measurement Measuring device Skill of person measuring Accuracy and precision are two separate concept Measurement Near target centre - Accurate Near each other - Precise Goal – to be accurate and precise Process Measuring instrument calibration Human skill and training Data – to be accurate and precise Method used to express accuracy and precision You can’t report numbers better than the method used to measure them 6.72 units = three significant figures Certain Digit Uncertain Digit Accuracy and Precision of
Measure Uncertainty of measurement Measuring device Skill of person measuring Accuracy and precision are two separate concept Measurement Near target centre - Accurate Near each other - Precise Goal – to be accurate and precise Process Measuring instrument calibration Human skill and training Data – to be accurate and precise Method used to express accuracy and precision You can’t report numbers better than the method used to measure them 6.72 units = three significant figures Certain Digit Uncertain Digit
section.related-content:
Every measurement has a degree of uncertainty associated with it. The uncertainty derives from the measuring device and the skill of the person doing the measuring.
Accuracy and precision are two separate concepts. The classic illustration distinguishing the two is to consider a target. Arrows surrounding a target center indicate a high degree of accuracy; arrows very near to each other (possibly nowhere near the target center) indicate a high degree of precision. To be accurate, an arrow must be near the target center; to be precise successive arrows must be near each other. Consistently hitting the very center of the target indicates both accuracy and precision.
Thermometers are notoriously inaccurate, often requiring re-calibration several times over the lifetime of the instrument. Scales also require recalibration, especially if they are moved or mistreated. Plant instrumentation needs to be calibrated and tested to be sure they are both accurate and precise. Also, the person doing the measurement must have a high degree of skill in the measurement process in order that the best measurement is made.
It is important in Industry that we are careful with our measurements so that they are both accurate and precise. We use those measurements to make decisions about the business we are in. Also, when we report data it is important that the data reflect the accuracy and precision of our measuring process.
In today’s world, with computers and calculators, since numbers can be calculated and result in many decimal places, we may use all the available decimal places to report that number. In the professional world that infers we have an accuracy and precision in the number of those many decimal places. Did adding more decimal points make it more accurate or more impressive? Of course not. The number should only be reported using the rules of “significant figures”. The main guidance of those rules is that you should not report a number better than the accuracy and precision of the method used to measure that number. In the illustration, the ruler can measure the pencil accurately only to whole centimeters - six. We can estimate one additional number 0.7 by estimating the distance between the six and seven. As a result we enter the result 6.7 centimeters for the result – two significant figures. If we continue to use this numerical measurement, we should always continue using it with the rules of significant figures to communicate the accuracy and precision of the original measurement – always two significant figures. In this way, anyone using our numbers will be consistent in transferring the information in our organization and accurately reflect the precision and accuracy.
